pullRequest.title: [DOCS] Improves find_file_structure documentation
pullRequest.bodyText:
This PR splits the example section of the find_file_structure documentation to subsections for improved readability.
It also adds:

a table on example time formats and their displayed values under timestamp_format,
a link pointing to the Java date/time format documentation.

Related issue: elastic/ml-team#274 (comment)
Preview: http://elasticsearch_50743.docs-preview.app.elstc.co/guide/en/elasticsearch/reference/master/ml-find-file-structure.html

nodes.bodyText:
This "NOTE" isn't showing up properly in the output and I think it's not necessary for this to be an admonition block.

  
    
      
        Suggested change
        
          
    

        
      
    
    
      
          
            
            NOTE: Only a subset of Java time format letter groups are supported:
          
          
            
            Only a subset of Java time format letter groups are supported:
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -159,13 +163,13 @@ also specified.
 For structured file formats, if you specify this parameter, the field must exist
 within the file.
 
-If this parameter is not specified, the structure finder makes a decision about which
-field (if any) is the primary timestamp field. For structured file formats, it
-is not compulsory to have a timestamp in the file.
+If this parameter is not specified, the structure finder makes a decision about 
+which field (if any) is the primary timestamp field. For structured file 
+formats, it is not compulsory to have a timestamp in the file.
 --
 
 `timestamp_format`::
-  (string) Optional. The Java time format of the timestamp field in the file. +
+  (Optional, string) The Java time format of the timestamp field in the file.
 +
 --
 NOTE: Only a subset of Java time format letter groups are supported:

nodes.bodyText:
Timeformat examples

I think rather than having this heading, we should provide a bit of introductory text.  Something like "The following table provides the appropriate timeformat values for some example timestamps:"
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -206,6 +210,20 @@ structure finder does not consider by default.
 If this parameter is not specified, the structure finder chooses the best
 format from a built-in set.
 
+Timeformat examples:

nodes.bodyText: In general, we just have one example for each API.  It seems to me that if this API ceases to be "experimental" we'll want to move and expand some of these examples out of the reference page so we get explain them more thoroughly. But for now, I think it's okay like this.
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -219,6 +237,9 @@ size, which defaults to 100 Mb.
 [[ml-find-file-structure-examples]]
 ==== {api-examples-title}
 
+[[ml-find-file-structure-example-nld-json]]
+===== Ingesting newline-delimited JSON
